title: Depressed Dads and Fun Withdrawal
opening_message: I've been noticing that after we have a good time together as a family, like during holidays or vacations, I often find myself feeling really down and disconnected from my loved ones once it's all over.

all: I struggle with feelings of low after stretches of particularly enjoyable times.
Halloween was a favorite holiday for my family, and returning to our normal routines felt like a drag.
For the past two weeks, I've struggled to engage with my wife and daughters (3, 1) because of this feeling.
This phenomenon happens not just after holidays, but also after family vacations, birthdays, or other joyful events.
The fun times feel like an escape from our normal routines, rather than the norm.
I've described this feeling to my wife as "fun withdrawal".
I'm looking forward to breaking out of my funk with the upcoming holidays.

turns.content: I've been noticing that after we have a good time together as a family, like during holidays or vacations, I often find myself feeling really down and disconnected from my loved ones once it's all over.

It sounds like you're experiencing a bit of a post-holiday blues, where the initial excitement and togetherness give way to feelings of sadness and disconnection. That can be tough to deal with, especially when it feels like you've built up this sense of closeness with your family. Can you tell me more about what's going through your mind during these times?

"Man, it's like...I feel like I'm just going through the motions, you know? Like, I'll be playing with the girls or watching a movie with my wife, but my mind is elsewhere. It's like I'm just pretending to be present, and deep down I'm feeling really disconnected from them. And worst part is, I don't even know how to snap out of it."

It sounds like you're struggling to truly be present in those moments with your loved ones, and that's causing a sense of disconnection and frustration for you. It can feel like you're just going through the motions, but deep down, you're craving more connection and intimacy. Can you tell me what you think might be driving this feeling of being disconnected?

"Ah, yeah... I think what's driving it is this feeling of being stuck in this 'afterglow' phase where everything feels great at first, and then suddenly crashes back down to reality. It's like, we just got back from this amazing vacation, everyone's happy, and then BAM! Back to the daily grind. And it's not just the lack of quality time, but more so... I don't know how to sustain that feeling of being present and connected with my family once the initial excitement wears off."

It sounds like you're experiencing a bit of a letdown after the initial high of a special event or vacation. You're craving a way to keep that sense of connection and joy going, but it's hard to sustain when life gets back to normal. Can you tell me what you think would help you feel more connected to your family on an everyday basis?

Man... I guess what I really wish was that we could just keep having those moments of pure connection and excitement all the time. You know, like when we're on vacation or at a sporting event together as a family. It feels like we're actually present and enjoying each other's company, you know?

It sounds like those special moments are really meaningful to you, and you'd love to bottle up that feeling and make it a regular part of your life with your family. Those moments can be powerful in bringing you all closer together. What do you think would need to change or happen for you to start experiencing more of those moments on an everyday basis?

"I guess I just want things to feel more special and exciting again, not just stuck in a routine. Like, Halloween was always a big deal with the kids, we'd dress up, go trick-or-treating... it was fun! But now that it's over, everything feels so mundane again. I don't know, maybe if we could find ways to make everyday feel like a special occasion or something, that would be awesome."

It sounds like you're craving a sense of excitement and joy in your daily life, rather than just going through the motions. You loved making memories with your family on holidays like Halloween, and now you want to find ways to bring that same magic into your everyday routine. Can you think of any small things you could do or try to make your days feel more special and exciting?

Man, yeah... I mean, it's like, I used to love doing stuff with the kids, whether it was a silly game or just hanging out and laughing together. Now, it feels like we're all just stuck in this routine and nothing seems fun anymore. Even little things that used to bring me joy, like playing video games or watching my favorite TV show, don't seem to cut it anymore. I guess what I'm saying is, I miss feeling like a kid again – carefree and excited about life.

It sounds like you're really missing the sense of joy and playfulness that comes with being a kid. You used to love doing silly things with your kids, but now it feels like that spark has fizzled out. Can you think of something you loved to do as a kid that you haven't done in a while? Maybe there's something that could bring back those feelings of carefree joy?

Yeah... I think about it, and I used to love building with Legos, making these crazy creations that my kids would stare at in awe. But honestly, it's been years since I've picked up a single brick. And now when I look back on those times, all I can think is "oh man, that was just a fleeting high" - like, I'll have this awesome moment with the kids, and then reality sets in and I'm back to being stressed out about work or whatever. It's like, I don't want to get my hopes up again only to have it all crash down... you know?

It sounds like you're hesitant to rekindle that sense of joy because you've been disappointed before. You're worried that if you start building with Legos again or doing something else that brings you happiness, it'll just be a temporary high and then the stress and reality will set back in. Can you think of anything that would make it feel safe for you to re-experience that joy without worrying about it not lasting?

"Ah, yeah... I guess I am worried about setting myself up for disappointment again. But with the holidays coming up, I feel like it's a chance to break free from this funk and have some fun with the kids. Maybe if I started small, just doing something simple like building a little Lego creation or playing a game with them, it could be a way to dip my toes back into that joy without feeling overwhelmed."
